questions.question: What is the meaning of justiciability?

choices.A: Justiciability refers to the possibility of enforcement of a particular right by the relevant rights holders
choices.B: Justiciability refers to the just nature or cause of a particular right
choices.C: Justiciability refers to the courts' assessment of whether the non-enforcement of a particular rights conforms to principles of justice
choices.D: Justiciability refers to the obligation of a State to enforce a particular Right

questions.question: What is the meaning of international legal personality?

choices.A: It means that only States are considered subjects of international law
choices.B: It means having rights and duties under international law and a capacity to enforce these by or against the relevant actor
choices.C: It means that an entity may challenge the authority of States
choices.D: It is a term that is meant to denote legal, as opposed, to physical persons under international law

questions.question: What is the principal source of immunity in respect of international organisations (IOs)?

choices.A: The principal source of immunity for IOs is the UN Charter
choices.B: The principal sources of immunity for IOs are headquarters agreements and multilateral treaties providing specific immunities
choices.C: The principal source of immunity for IOs is customary law
choices.D: The principal source of immunity for IOs is the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Immunities

choices.A: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are part of a unified legal system
choices.B: Under dualism, international and domestic laws comprise distinct legal Systems
choices.C: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are distinct but equal in hierarchy
choices.D: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are distinct legal systems whereby domestic law always prevails

questions.question: What is the meaning of "act of State" doctrine?

choices.A: The act of State doctrine denotes that all State acts attract immunity
choices.B: The act of State doctrine denotes that the assessment as to the existence of an alleged tort committed by a State belongs to the executive and not the courts
choices.C: The act of State doctrine denotes that the courts are well placed to assess the existence of an alleged tort committed by the State
choices.D: The act of State doctrine is a legal mechanism that allows the courts to provide immunity to public acts of foreign States
